passages.text: 2025 results below on lower ViP hold. Acquire additional space at Old Lisboa to minimize GGR leakage from satellite casino closure; Neutral
0880.HK 12m Price Target: HK\\$3.10 Price: HK\\$3.34 Downside: 7.2%

As flagged in our preview report (Jul 10), SJM could be the only casino operator posting EBITDA contraction in 2Q25 on market share loss. Indeed, its headline EBITDA fell sharply by - 28% qoq to HK\\$688mn due to lower VIP win rate of 2.4% particularly in Apr and Jun (vs. 3.7% in 1Q25). Adjusting it back to theoretical 3.3%, it would have dropped less by - 13% qoq to HK\\$802mn (vs. HK\\$918mn in 1Q25) more inline with our estimate of

HK\\$802mn but well below consensus of HK\\$0.8- 1.05bn. The sequential EBITDA decline was mainly dragged by Grand Lisboa Palace (GLP) whose EBITDA dipped into - HK\\$66mn loss or a modest profit of +HK\\$48mn if adjusted for its lower VIP win rate of 1.9% (vs. +HK\\$149mn in 1Q25) on negative operating leverage against softer trends across all segments. Contribution from Grand Lisboa, Oceanus/Old Lisboa and satellite casinos also dropped - 4%, - 10% and - 5% qoq to HK\\$422mn, HK\\$309mn and HK\\$75mn respectively. For the group as a whole, its mass-market/slot GGR was - 2%/+1% qoq lagging behind the industry (+6%) while its VIP rolling volume tracked ahead +10% qoq vs. flat for the market. Non- gaming revenue also retreated by - 10% qoq on - 5% lower average hotel ADR at GLP. Amid intense competition, the group was able to keep its promotional allowance quite stable - 2% qoq representing 8.14% GGR (vs. 8% in 1Q25) - this is much lower than 18- 22% for other casino operators as SJM serves mostly the middle or grid and mass players requiring less rebates. Daily opex for its self- promoted casinos (GLP, GL, Old Lisboa, Oceanus) rose +4% qoq to HK\\$21.8mn (or US\\$2.8mn).
Looking into more details by individual casinos - as discussed in our
Market cap: HK\\$18.5bn / \\$2.4bn Enterprise value: HK\\$42.7bn / \\$5.5bn 3m ADTV: HK\\$75.5mn / \\$9.6mn Hong Kong Asia Leisure M&A Rank: 3

sector report (Jul 2), GLP's ramp- up appears to have lost steam with mass- market GGR \(- 5\%\) qoq (vs. \(+14\% /2\%\) in 4Q24/1Q25). Its GGR market share slipped to \(2.3\%\) (vs. \(2.7\% /2.8\%\) in 4Q24/1Q25) at similar scale as Parisian \((2.7\%)\) and Plaza \((2.3\%)\) in Cotai. In Peninsula, Grand, GGR (GL)'s mass/slot GGR was more stable, i.e., flat \(+3\%\) qoq, while VIP rolling volume dropped \(- 20\%\) qoq since some junket rooms were undergoing renovation to be turned into hotel rooms. Overall, SJM lost - 1.2pts GGR market share up to \(12.3\%\) in 2Q25 (Rolling volume: \(+0.7\) pts qoq to \(8.3\%\) , mass/slot GGR: - 1pts qoq to \(13.4\%\) ). As of end- 1H25, the group had HK\$3.3bn cash on hand and HK\$3.1bn undrawn facilities. Net debt stood at HK\$21.9bn implying \(6.3x\) net debt to EBITDA (vs. \(5.9x\) as of end- 1Q25).

Compared to their tone in prior results call, we found management sounding more cautious about their business outlook this time around, potentially reflecting choppy operating performance and market share in recent months. From our channel checks, we understand that SJM's GGR market share slipped again to below \(12\%\) so far in Aug after bouncing back to \(12.8\%\) in July (vs. \(12.3\%\) in 2Q25), although GLP has performed better vs. satellite casinos in general. Most of the questions at the call were related to its strategies to minimize GGR/EBITDA leakage upon the closure of its satellite casinos by the end of this year, esp. since the group has received confirmation from the government to take back all 440 gaming tables there. The additional cost they will have to bear by taking over the \(\sim 3k\) staff working at these satellite casinos are sunk costs. Other than its earlier announcement to acquire 2 out of its 9 satellite casinos in Peninsula, i.e., Casino L'Arc Macau, Casino Ponte 16 (see our report on Jun 11), the group also announced after the market closed on Aug 28th (link) that it will acquire additional space totaling \(7.5k\) sqm at Old Lisboa from its parentco STDM for a total consideration of HK\$529mn - their intention, per the announcement, is for the group to house some of the gaming tables taken back from the satellite casinos. For context, SJM currently owns 1/16 of Old Lisboa for its existing gaming area and the remaining 15/16 is controlled by STDM. According to management, they plan to double its gaming table capacity by installing \(\sim 80\) gaming tables in the new area. If we assume each table generates similar US\$8k daily revenue as those currently in operation at Old Lisboa, they together could generate \(\sim US\$230mn\) or HK\$1.9bn annualized GGR or \(0.7\%\) GGR market share. Netting out gaming tax, promotional allowance, staff and other fixed costs (some of which are sunk costs), we estimate up to \(\sim HK\$0.5bn\) in potential EBITDA accretion based on company guidance. Assuming successful execution on the announced terms, we see strategic merit in this proposed acquisition. However, we see risks to potential returns SJM could realize from the acquisition of the two satellite casinos (L'Arc and Pone 16) which could cost up to HK\$3- 6bn when benchmarked with the valuation of adjacent properties (HK\$ 20- 40k/sqm) as discussed in our prior report (Jun 11). Exhibit 3 lays out the EBITDA impact to the group depending on how much GGR market share it can retain out of the approximately \(5\%\) share these 9 satellite casino used to generate. Our analysis suggests that SJM could break even for as long as it retains more than \(\sim 2\%\) GGR market share - we model \(2.3\%\) translating to HK\$4.7bn EBITDA in FY26E. Our forecast does not factor in any incomplete transactions.
Another concern often raised by investors in our conversations is the group's

financial position and capital resources available for its various projects and acquisitions. These include (1) HK\$803mn for the planned acquisition of Hengqin office and its conversion into 3- star hotel rooms to be completed in 2 years; (2) the above- mentioned HK\$529mn acquisition of additional gaming space at Old Lisboa; (3) additional consideration to acquire 2 satellite casinos, which could cost up to HK\$3- 6bn. In addition, we note that SJM still has HK\$5.4bn debt maturity next year. Exhibit 4 lays out its projected cashflow in FY25- 27E. Despite these significant capital requirements, management reiterated that they would not fund it with new equity issuance, but with new debt or debt refinancing.

On results, we revise our FY25- 27E EBITDA for SJM by \(- 12\%\) to \(+2\%\) . Rolling over to FY26E, we revise our 12- month SOTP- based target price to HK\$3.1 (from HK\$2.7). This set of results reaffirms our concern that (1) GLP ramp up is losing steam as low hanging fruits from earlier initiatives have been picked; and (2) its recently announced acquisitions could further leverage SJM's stretched balance sheet and delay its dividend resumption. This said, we believe successful execution on its planned acquisition of additional space at Old Lisboa would help minimize GGR leakage from its satellite casino closures. Maintain Neutral.

SJM is one of six Macau based casino operators. We are Neutral rated as a relative call, considering (1) Grand Lisboa Palace (GLP) ramp up is losing steam as the low hanging fruit from new initiatives have been picked; (2) Increased competition on the Peninsula; and (3) Acquiring the 2 satellite casinos could further leverage SJM's stretched balance sheet and delay its dividend resumption. Valuation looks fair compared to industry peers on EV/EBITDA.
HK\$3.1. Our TP is based on a 2026E EV/EBITDA driven SOTP.

Key risks: (1) stronger/weaker execution and further ramp- up of GLP closer to \(5 - 7\%\) GGR market share; (2) more/less effective use of the gaming tables taken back from satellite casinos in other properties.

I, Simon Cheung, CFA, hereby certify that all of the views expressed in this report accurately reflect my personal views about the subject company or companies and its or their securities. I also certify that no part of my compensation was, is or will be, directly or indirectly, related to the specific recommendations or views expressed in this report.
Unless otherwise stated, the individuals listed on the cover page of this report are analysts in Goldman Sachs' Global Investment Research division.

The Goldman Sachs Factor Profile provides investment context for a stock by comparing key attributes to the market (i.e. our universe of rated stocks) and its sector peers. The four key attributes depicted are: Growth, Financial Returns, Multiple (e.g. valuation) and Integrated (a composite of Growth, Financial Returns and Multiple). Growth, Financial Returns and Multiple are calculated by using normalized ranks for specific metrics for each stock. The normalized ranks for the metrics are then averaged and converted into percentiles for the relevant attribute. The precise calculation of each metric may vary depending on the fiscal year, industry and region, but the standard approach is as follows:

Growth is based on a stock's forward- looking sales growth, EBITDA growth and EPS growth (for financial stocks, only EPS and sales growth), with a higher percentile indicating a higher growth company. Financial Returns is based on a stock's forward- looking ROE, ROCE and CROCI (for financial stocks, only ROE), with a higher percentile indicating a company with higher financial returns. Multiple is based on a stock's forward- looking P/E, P/B, price/dividend (P/D), EV/EBITDA, EV/FCF and EV/Debt Adjusted Cash Flow (DACF) (for financial stocks, only P/E, P/B and P/D), with a higher percentile indicating a stock trading at a higher multiple. The Integrated percentile is calculated as the average of the Growth percentile, Financial Returns percentile and (100% - Multiple percentile).

Financial Returns and Multiple use the Goldman Sachs analyst forecasts at the fiscal year- end at least three quarters in the future. Growth uses inputs for the fiscal year at least seven quarters in the future compared with the year at least three quarters in the future (on a per- share basis for all metrics).
For a more detailed description of how we calculate the GS Factor Profile, please contact your GS representative.

Across our global coverage, we examine stocks using an M&A framework, considering both qualitative factors and quantitative factors (which may vary across sectors and regions) to incorporate the potential that certain companies could be acquired. We then assign a M&A rank as a means of scoring companies under our rated coverage from 1 to 3, with 1 representing high (30%- 50%) probability of the company becoming an acquisition target, 2 representing medium (15%- 30%) probability and 3 representing low (0%- 15%) probability. For companies ranked 1 or 2, in line with our standard departmental guidelines we incorporate an M&A component into our target price. M&A rank of 3 is considered immaterial and therefore does not factor into our price target, and may or may not be discussed in research.

Quantum is Goldman Sachs' proprietary database providing access to detailed financial statement histories, forecasts and ratios. It can be used for in- depth analysis of a single company, or to make comparisons between companies in different sectors and markets.

Buy (B), Neutral (N), Sell (S) Analysts recommend stocks as Buys or Sells for inclusion on various regional Investment Lists. Being assigned a Buy or Sell on an Investment List is determined by a stock's total return potential relative to its coverage universe. Any stock not assigned as a Buy or a Sell on an Investment List with an active rating (i.e., a stock that is not Rating Suspended, Not Rated, Early- Stage Biotech, Coverage Suspended or Not Covered), is deemed Neutral. Each region manages Regional Conviction Lists, which are selected from Buy rated stocks on the respective region's Investment Lists and represent investment recommendations focused on the size of the total return potential and/or the likelihood of the realization of the return across their respective areas of coverage. The addition or removal of stocks from such Conviction Lists are managed by the Investment Review Committee or other designated committee in each respective region and do not represent a change in the analysts' investment rating for such stocks.

Total return potential represents the upside or downside differential between the current share price and the price target, including all paid or anticipated dividends, expected during the time horizon associated with the price target. Price targets are required for all covered stocks. The total return potential, price target and associated time horizon are stated in each report adding or reiterating an Investment List membership.
Coverage Universe: A list of all stocks in each coverage universe is available by primary analyst, stock and coverage universe at https://www.gs.com/research/hedge.html.
